text:
Weyburn Park Box 96

May 31, 1952

I am sorry I did not get the papers filled in before as I have had so much work.

That sickness in the house is the reason I could not be there if what I say is true.

All right as to many of the young people made fun of me at old times, and think I'm just a joker, but you who know me know it was no joke, if I had the education I would have a book on my life that the children now don't.

Take the good of the past, and every thing changes with years, but many fond memories still remain of the old days.

P.S. If I have not made everything clear I shall be glad to further explain.

S. G.
Weyburn Bank Box 964

May 8th / 1952

I am sorry I did not get the papers filled in before we had back J. about a month.

That sickness in the house is the reason I would like to know if what I stated in was all right or not.

I was one of the young people who came from old times and knew it was a joke, but you see who came to the city.

It was one of the things that the children now don't want to work at any time that they could take the good of the actions, that every thing changes with years, but many fond memories stay remains of the old days.

P.S. If I have not made everything clear I shall be glad to further explain.
This is just a sketch of life in Man. I myself

You will not want to work in the Province.

Well we were dried out on the plains and drowned

out by floods too much rain and mosquitoes were some

thing terrible and the 4 hours we did save from

that prairie did not do well on the damp field and

grass up there. Did no bridges on the river road or

roads good there or make roads for to take our

moving effect across and everyone build big houses

had bees as they called them. From Breegs had a

store for staple groceries and food. The mail train in

the 28 miles from Dauphin by train, R. R. was

you at big log house for the mail came in every 2

weeks day. The rate of their were so high and the rate

every one would go there for the house and the rate

telegraph post office in our hand. The house was in worth

Fell down and all hands and its 7 bachelors who could play

so we had lot fun and its 7 bachelors who could play

The badly and nice of a big income one to call and

many a good time we all had. That, plenty I all wild

meat but little off their on the farm so

fruit and lot of games so

have been scarce, well then was no school for them and

the R.R. came right through. We had

settled on, and had the town 8 mile from our farm.
This is just a sketch of life in Man. I myself

were we were dried out on the plains and drowned

out by fires too much rain and mosquitoes were some

thing terrible and the 4 horses we did save from

that prairie did not do well on the damp field and

cross up there, every one lost horses from the difficult

move after flood they or make the rafts for to take our

moving effect across, and everyone build big houses

had been as they called them. From Bridge, had a

store for staple groceries and food the mail train in

the 28 miles from Dauphin by team, & Bader

great trip to town Royal and the mail came in every 2

weeks, after the rate of flies worse so that everybody

would gaff for the house, and the rate

many a good time we all had, plenty food was

meat and butter off their on the flat, plenty food was

fruit and lots of games so the girls always took a

hard clear course, well then was no schools there and

the R.R. come right through the town little over

miles on, and had the town 8 mile from our farm.
Manitoba

Well as I had no chance for school, so always did. For
Cora and Mother and all her sisters working good cards
so I had taken to tid-1 and was always to go out-
to earn money for my self, and when I was 17 my
self and two other girls & full playing Bell we all
went to Winnipeg to work, I got a job at Princess
Hotel's House. Afterward I went to the Prince George
Premier. I worked there from September the next year
was in Winnipeg at the time the Mounted Police
called me to go to the Boer War. I was remembered how
the Winnipeg streets were such crowds and the Baud
play ing. In June I went to Hope N. Duk and got Heston
better in a small Hotel. I loved cooking and one has to
do again things when you don't have any education and
have had a lot hard work but never let any thing get
down, had a house of friends, and my health off course
seen a lot of the country, was to follow store work out by
California, and a few months of New Mexico, and then
for Laramie, Quebec City and after North on the Pan Man
for weeks this as it seemed and be too try a short stay
between the times I had came find old the town came to
see the past years. But glad the old prairie's advantages
takes the best although they
in Mani Man on the prairie.
Manitoba

Well as I had no chance for school, so always did. To
Cora and mother and all her sisters working in the
city, I had taken to tidy up and was always to go out
to earn money for my self, and when I was 17 my
self and two other girls & I had a doggy Bell we all
went to Winnipeg to work, I got a job at Princess
Hotel's House, worked there from September the 2nd
Premier, I worked there from September the 2nd
was in Winnipeg at the time, the memories were all
called in to go to the Bon Wan, I can remember how
the Winnipeg streets were such crowds and the Baud
playings, I went to Hope N. Dak. and put myself
in a small Hotel, I loved cooking and one has to
do again things where you don't have any education
and I have had a lot of work but never too many things
down, had a house of friends and my friends often
seen a lot of the country, went to Yellow Stone Park
out West, California, and a few months of New Mexico
for sure, Quebec City and also on North on the Pan Man
for sure, this could not be too try a short stay runs
between the times I had came first and the third came to
see the panty fans, looking for the old prairie's advantages
takes the truth although they were lots more advantages
in man than on the plains.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (already answered this) and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (already answered this).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archivist Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If there is not enough space to describe particular events, or if they help to answer the question, write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience at the pioneer stage of their life. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, they should be written on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your discretion, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: MRS. GRACE GREIG
2. Your address: WEYBURN, SASK/894
3. Date: 1882
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) AVON, ROCKY MOUNTAIN COUNTY, WISCONSIN
5. What was your father's name and occupation? FARMER, CAYUETTE
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) APRIL 1892, MOVED BY GEORGE GRAHAM FROM BRITISH COLUMBIA (ALBERTA, WHEN 18 YEARS OLD)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. 3 MONTHS IN RED DEER, ALBERTA, THEN TO WYHURNE IN 1902, NEW YORK STATE
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not.) I WAS IN MY TEENS
9. What were your reasons for coming West? FAMILY COMES BECAUSE HE HAD 4 CHILDREN
10. How did you learn about the West? THROUGH OTHER PEOPLE? READING ABOUT IT
11. Railroad or government information? BOOKS, WILL-TO-PAY PRICES FOR WESTERN INFORMATION
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your direction, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: MRS. GRACE GREIG/GAX
2. Your address: WEYBURN, SASK/894
3. Date: 1/8/82
4. Where were you living? (Give name of town and country) AVON, ROCKY MOUNTAIN COUNTY
5. What was your father's name and occupation? WILLIAM NORTON
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) APRIL 1892
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. 3 months in British Columbia, then moved to Weyburn in 1902.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you were in my teens, etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming west?
10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?

Additional notes:
- Father came because he had 4½ acres of land in S.D.A.K., and Red River district.
- Some years did not get rain, but also owned 2 acres of land in W.Y./2 Section 3, Township 3, Range 31, also broke 80 acres of land in Section 14, Township 3, Range 31, and got one cow and two calves.
- But full time work for the Taylor family, who lived near us.
- (said we called them) a pioneer family, standing crops as lovely as ours, but not a house. So not sure if they were out by C.P.R., but not a house.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought we were very good at what we did, but not very good at what we didn't do.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the road, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you settle or take up land in Western Canada?

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Western Canada.

17. How many acres of land did you own in Western Canada?
continued.

If we had been able to see our homes and cattle dying in White for lack of grain, as I can not remember whether Political Party was in power, but I know all Hi-Righ they gave away. We were used for to pay, and that was paid against our home stead by us could get the hatred. We don't know what we could have stood over us without, and one of the hatchboards (with house stranded over us) had been in the North West Rebellion and also worked on the C.P.R., when it was being put through. The Mts. and in the Nanaimo area and the office they were Daddy McDooley riding on the cow Ritter within 1887 if was promised to Vaudry well he moved at the same time all the settlers did over to Fort River Daily (Lin. Dis.) and when he tried his own other house stand in town so after years here he moved up to his house, house stand the final payed $500.00 for $500.00 worth of wood the land was given him at CARIEVALE, 9 months though Zhal-was a very fair deal for an old soldier his name was George Nickleos.

My Father and other neighbors would take wagons and go to Okanagan Falls, 60 or 70 miles north of us and if we had taken the 40 day to make the trip and bring them dry hophular hol's food wood in Summer land and we also travel the dry cow pasture in the fall and in the spring. In the 30's where the 2nd dried out of grass in my life, and so many people made remarks about the crops and said if half they gave us, I tried though they should be been thankful for that, not like the years when B was a good hard worker for that of any thing.
I was asked to sell our house and cattle during the Whittier for lack of grain, as you not necessarily under political party was in power, but I knew all the people they gave away. We were paid for $200, and that wasn't enough against our house. If we could get the hatred-dead, then we could get started. Lots of people satirically said, "And one of the hatchetmen who have attacked other men had been in the North West Rebellion and also worked on the C.P.R., when he was young, but he went to the N.W.T.

and in the Vancouver and the other town, we got ready to be killed if we continued to ride on the cow pasture unless money was paid. If we continued to travel well, he moved at the same time all the settlers did over to Fort River (Big Bay) and when we took our other house stand in town as often (sic) Henry the proved up on his house, house stand the field. Payed $500 worth of wood the land off.

$500 worth of wood the land off.

gave him a CARAVELLE, 9 months through the winter.

a very fair deal for an old soldier.

Brooke Mitchell

my family and other neighbors would take wagons and go to Prince Rupert, boos 70 miles north of us and take the dry hay for 5 days to make the trip and bring it back dry popular hol food wood in summer time and we also brought the dry cow manure.

In the 30's when the land dried out, we were left, and so many people made remarks about the crops and decided that they were just though. They should have been thankful for that, not for the grass which was good and had no help for them or any thing.
CARIEVALE, THORF RIVER, DAUPHIN, N.D., M.M., and Weyburn.

ANCESTRY IN WEYBURN.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Often but
did not get mail regular, and my father took the family
heralds and a paper from S. Dak., so by the watches had extensive
but we had horses.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
and place of marriage. Hugh Grey & WEYBURN Nov. who had a
big cypress house at the time I married. My
husband had been to Prince Albert at we could go show
WEYBURN. After six years, he moved
out and bought 3 more acres and so we still live in the same
place.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
tell when they came and where they settled. No.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your
memory which you would like to record?
At Carievale, there was 3 brothers whose father was the first physician
in Pender creek from Pilot Mound herein. The son went
home early. Before his parents came and they
lived there, and shortly afterwards he had an hospital of their
own. They were always doing some good deed for none because
ni politics or trouble. And they helped others after all, in co-op
order and
afterwards had nice farms located in Carievale and many of them

Fixtures were John Nelson, James Carrie. My mother's Father said they
were the finest people anyone could know.

24. Did you travel at much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
visiting friends, etc.)
Went around on horseback and the old Henry Bulette built cars.
He did early schooling in the school where affixed was built in
6699, but only had school in the months of a married woman until
her 29, as Slide's Hill are almost six miles away across a big river and after two
she taught the months from June, July and August, first same room away
to broketh right arm as could not put on other teacher and
Sit dry years above so that we all the Reapers who were little
lived at Pender Creek, Carievale, the teachers were ours.

HORATIO TITUS.
The RR was built through Carievale and Carievale in 1895, and
I old country scots, who were there before us, R.R. one had a girl friend
in old country. We moved to Carievale, which we rebuilt at
our town hall. She never lived to come to this country. John Young's brother,
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1907, owned by Mr. Mosby Harris agent.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes it an automobile?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? 3 miles Weyburn.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appearing, laws, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? 1918 or thereabouts.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your purchases came by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1910

33. When you came to Stashabawen the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We always liked it. This wouldn't be fair. It's better than the NS, as not so much work on Sundays, and no stores open then.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1907.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? What model?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? 3 miles.

28. Did you have any changes due to new towns appearing?

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays? 1918

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any change in this proportion caused by your move since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1910

33. When did you come to Saskatchewan the first time? Make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make this decision? We always did hear this story. This morning, Mr. [signature] letter, Feb. 14th, we met so much worse on Sundays, and no others open this...
6. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old photos and pictures, old newspapers, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Mrs. Donald, my oldest daughter,

Box 964 Weyburn, S.W. West. 442 Hillside Ave., Suburban Ont.

43. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since the first came west?

Electricity which the Government put in this District in July 1949.
Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old postcards and photographs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names where they live and occupations.

Box 9645 Weyburn, Box 9645 WEST, 442, HILL'S DE AOE, SUBURB ONT.

Electricity which the Government put in this District in July 1949.

Harold Jacobsen, Box 9645 Weyburn.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this question.

Harold Jacobsen, Box 9645 Weyburn.
